subject: Re: [junit] Re: Unit Testing vs Integration Testing
msgSnippet: ... Google Learning Tests . In short, the idea is to formalize how you think the third-party API behaves in tests, then using that information with confidence
messageBody:
>So said Mike Bresnahan on 2003-06-20 --------------------
>A problem that I am very often faced with is writing some code that
>interacts with a 3rd party API which I am unfamiliar with. In these cases
>it seems counter productive to create unit tests for my own code when I
>have
>no idea whether my code will actually work when used with the 3rd party
>API.
>I could end up wasting a lot time writing and testing code that is designed
>incorrectly. In these cases, it seems more sensical to me to write
>integration tests which involve both my code and the 3rd party API. How do
>people more familiar with unit testing handle such situations?

Google "Learning Tests".

In short, the idea is to formalize how you think the third-party API behaves in tests, then using that information with confidence to write your own objects. It's not something that one strictly follows, necessarily, but there is one definite advantage to writing Learning Tests.

When I worked at IBM, my component used third-party software from HNC Software. I would typically test my code using my knowledge of how HNC's software works. Of course, my knowledge was imperfect, and occasionally the whole would not work even though the parts did. (Here I use "work" to mean "behave as expected".) Obviously some expectation of mine was incorrect, so I began writing Learning Tests against HNC's product, which both verified my assumptions and codified them for the next poor sap who has to maintain my software. In the process, I wrote a failing test, which I shipped to HNC and which they used to fix the problem within two days.

The key here is that I gave them a failing test, rather than a vague description of the problem. That eliminated the cost figuring out just what I meant by "Blah blah blah doesn't do fizzlefazzle." They commented that having the failing test allowed them to fix the problem in an hour and that the two-day turnaround was the result of their laborious release process.

So Learning Tests gave me a few things:

* An unambiguous specification of the assumptions that underlie my code
* A way to verify my assumptions against the product I'm using
* An unambiguous way to communicate problems to the company providing the software to me

Based on that, I considered the technique a winner.
